thread.title: Easton girls' trophy quest snags two more at EPC cross country championship
thread.title_full: Easton girls' trophy quest snags two more at EPC cross country championship

title: Easton girls' trophy quest snags two more at EPC cross country championship
text:
Complete Box Score » 
If Easton’s girls cross country team needs a theme song, we have the perfect fit. 
“All I want Is Everything,” a classic Southside Johnny and the Asbury Jukes song from the late 1970’s, matches the Rovers’ mood this postseason. 
Easton’s all-encompassing desire for hardware dominated Tuesday afternoon’s Eastern Pennsylvania Conference championships at the Bethlehem Municipal Executive Golf Course. 
“We didn’t want just one trophy this year,” said senior quad-captain Diana Hammerstone said. “We want to win everything this year.” 
The Rovers are certainly off to a good start en route to that goal. After going 17-0 in the EPC regular season Easton stormed to the championship meet title with 52 points to runner-up Stroudsburg’s 84, and thus collected two big trophies at the meet’s award ceremonies. 
Tuesday’s championship meet triumph was something the Rovers had targeted since last year at this time when Parkland edged Easton out. While the Rovers came back the next week to win the District 11 Class AAA championship, the loss to the Trojans rankled. 
“Losing to Parkland was a lot of motivation for us,” said Easton junior quad-captain Alyssa Repsher. “We remembered last year. We wanted two trophies this year.” 
The Rovers made sure there would be no repeat by placing five runners in the top 17 Tuesday, led by Hammerstone in second place in 19:06, followed by freshman Lauren Maddison (eighth, 19:50); sophomore Katie Ellmaker (10th, 20:00; Repsher (15th, 20:14) and senior Megan Korn (17th, 20:23) 
“I think we improved ourselves mentally and physically from last year, and it showed in this meet,” Korn said. 
Easton coach Bobbi Jo Powell will have a problem when she selects her top seve for the D-11 meet on the same course Oct. 28. 
“We’re 10 deep, and the JV girls are right there too,” Powell said. “This is a good problem to have. These girls have gone two years unbeaten in the league and that’s not easy to do. I think this group just jelled together this year.” 
Easton junior quad-captain Olivia George said a close team in 2014 came even closer this fall. “We had a lot of freshmen come on this team, and I think we had bonded as a team even better than we did last year,” George said. 
While Hammerstone is the on-course leader, behind her could come any number of girls in any order, depending on the race, and that’s a huge strength for Easton. 
“We never worry about the order we finish with each other,” George said. “We just want to do the best we can for the team.” 
“Every girl on this team has the team mentality,” Korn said. 
And, the way things are going for Easton, every girl might wind up with a trophy, because all the Rovers want is everything.
